facts.text: Appellant was a tenant for about 20 years in premises known as Fida Ali Villa in Kalyan.
Building purchased by respondent who gave notice to appellant to vacate as he wanted to construct a new building on the site.
Appellant agreed to vacate and respondent let to him a portion of his new building not far from Fida Ali Villa.
Appellant had four sub-tenants; three shifted to new premises let to appellant; fourth (Bohri) fixed up by respondent elsewhere.
Courts below found sub-tenants occupied same position qua appellant.
Dispute on date new premises let: appellant alleged July 1, 1948; respondent June 1, 1948; trial court found June 1, 1948.
Terms of lease contained in document dated June 7, 1948, letter in Marathi by respondent to appellant permitting sub-tenants 'in the same manner' as in old chawl.
On January 3, 1949, respondent gave notice to appellant to vacate on ground of non-payment of rent and sub-letting, terminating tenancy.
On April 20, 1949, respondent filed suit for ejectment on grounds of non-payment of rent and sub-letting (Suit No. 153 of 1949).
Appellant defended claiming right to sub-let under lease terms; deposited arrears of rent in court.
Trial Court (Civil Judge, J.D. Kalyan, judgment January 31, 1952): sub-letting lawful despite s.15; not same terms as old premises; decree for Rs.445 rent; dismissed ejectment.
Appeal to Assistant Judge, Thana (C.A. No. 97 of 1952, judgment April 25, 1953): reversed, s.15 prohibits sub-letting, s.13(1)(e) allows eviction; order of ejectment.
Revision to Bombay High Court (C.R. Application No. 1213 of 1953, judgment August 10, 1955): affirmed order of ejectment.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court (Civil Appeal No. 674 of 1957).
Courts below held tenancy by letter June 7, 1948 was new tenancy, not continuation of old; sub-tenants tenants of appellant, not licensees of respondent.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss.13(1)(e) and 15 of Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 apply as there was no new tenancy after coming into force of the Act.
Whether appellant sub-let premises to sub-tenants or they were licensees of landlord.
Whether s.15 confined to other laws and does not apply to contracts between landlord and tenant, precluding agreement as to sub-letting.
Whether parties in pari delicto, respondent cannot succeed.
Whether respondent waived right under s.13(1)(e) by permitting sub-letting.

petitioner_arguments.text: No new tenancy after coming into force of Act, ss.13(1)(e) and 15 do not apply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 ss.13(1)(e), 15

petitioner_arguments.text: Tenant did not sub-let; sub-tenants merely licensees of landlord.
S.15 confined to any other law, does not apply to contracts; agreement permitting sub-letting valid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 s.15; Cooper v. Shiavax Cambatta

petitioner_arguments.text: Parties in pari delicto; plaintiff-respondent cannot succeed.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: In pari delicto potior est conditio possidentis

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent waived right to evict under s.13(1)(e) by contract permitting sub-letting.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 s.13(1)(e); Gouri Dutt Ganesh Lal Firm v. Madho Prasad

respondent_arguments.text: Sub-letting prohibited by s.15; right to evict under s.13(1)(e).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 ss.13(1)(e), 15

court_reasoning.text: Tenancy by letter June 7, 1948 was new tenancy, not continuation; previous tenancy ended; no privity between respondent and sub-tenants; they are tenants of appellant.
S.15 prohibits sub-letting notwithstanding any law, including contracts; non-obstante clause overrides T.P. Act s.108 and Contract Act; agreement contrary to s.15 unenforceable (s.23 Contract Act).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement to sub-let void as prohibited by law.

court_reasoning.text: S.13(1)(e) subject to s.15; must read together; landlord entitled to evict for sub-letting post-Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suit enforces statutory right, not illegal agreement.

court_reasoning.text: Pari delicto does not apply; respondent enforces statutory eviction remedy, not agreement; cannot assert right from illegal transaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction: remedy against infraction of s.15.

court_reasoning.text: Waiver plea not raised below, mixed question of fact/law; even if allowed, cannot enforce illegal agreement contravening s.15 public policy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No court enforces prohibited contract; waiver of illegality void.

court_reasoning.text: S.15 based on public policy; waiver in derogation of statutory right against public policy inoperative.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disclosure of illegality fatal; taints stipulation to waive.

holdings.text: New tenancy created post-Act; ss.13(1)(e), 15 apply; sub-tenants are tenants of appellant.
Agreement permitting sub-letting void under s.15 and s.23 Contract Act.
Pari delicto maxim inapplicable; statutory eviction right enforceable.
Waiver of right under s.13(1)(e) invalid as contravenes public policy of s.15.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. D. Aswani v. Kavashah Dinshah Mulla

precedents_cited.relevance: Under different Act (Bom. VII of 1944 s.10 permitting sub-letting); non-obstante clauses differ from s.15.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bowmakers Ltd. v. Barnet Instruments Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: True meaning of in pari delicto; waiver of illegality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gibbs Sterret Manufacturing Co. v. Brucker
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot assert right from illegal transaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gouri Dutt Ganesh Lal Firm v. Madho Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Pleader to set up facts, legal inferences drawable later.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: No court enforces invalid enactment; cannot dispense by consent.
Cannot condone statutory infraction by conduct.
Illegality fatal wherever appears; waiver tainted.
Court will not enforce forbidden acts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Norwich Corporation v. Norwich Electric Tramways Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory provision in public interest not waivable.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 (Bom. 57 of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: S.15 prohibits sub-letting post-Act; s.13(1)(e) entitles landlord to evict for sub-letting, subject to s.15; public policy.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Would allow sub-letting but overridden by s.15 non-obstante.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Agreement prohibited by law void and unenforceable.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; judgment of Bombay High Court affirmed confirming order of ejectment passed by Assistant Judge, Thana, on ground of sub-letting in contravention of s.15 read with s.13(1)(e) of Bombay Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; ejectment to respondent upheld.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything contained in any law it shall not be lawful after the coming into operation of this Act for any tenant to sub-let the whole or any part of the premises let to him or to assign or transfer in any other manner his interest therein."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is not permissible to any person to rely upon a contract the making of which the law prohibits (s.23 of the Contract Act)."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "No Court can enforce as valid that which competent enactments have declared shall not be valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Surajmull; cannot enforce illegal agreement.

key_quotes.text: "A waiver in derogation of a statutory right is not favoured, and a waiver will be inoperative and void, if it infringes on the rights of others, or would be against public policy or morals."
key_quotes.speaker: court
